posts.post_content: A fantastic addition to Knight tribal, and one of Soulbond's poster children. Double Strike is already a scary ability, but giving it to two creatures? For ![1](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=1&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)![White](/Handlers/Image.ashx?size=small&name=W&type=symbol)? And one of those could be a [Wolfir Silverheart](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Wolfir Silverheart) or a [Pathbreaker Wurm](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Pathbreaker Wurm)? I rarely got the chance to play the Paladin at the prerelease, but he won the game every time he hit the board.

posts.post_content:
@nopemx6:  
  
Actually, MyHappySandwich's plan works just fine. Drop the [Geist of Saint Traft](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Geist of Saint Traft) on turn 3, and make your opponent hate you more by dropping this fellow turn 4 and NOT soulbonding to the Geist. When Geist attacks, this triggers the 4/4 Flying Angel to enter the battlefield tapped and attacking, which triggers another "dost thou desire to soul bond?" trigger. This time, you gleefully accept, producing your turn four 4/4 Flying, Double Strike Angel of doom swinging in.  
  
The best part is that once the angel token is exiled at the end of combat, Mr. Silverblade Paladin here is now unpaired, and free to be paired with the next 4/4 Flying Angel produced on the next attack, and then on the Second Main Phase of turn 5 with your new jerk of a 5/3 Flying, Indestructible, Double Strike [Angelic Overseer](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Angelic Overseer) (Yay for this guy being a Human!).  
  
...Unless you were just saying you wanted Taft to survive due to Double Strike, in which case sometime... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)
posts.html:
@nopemx6:

Actually, MyHappySandwich's plan works just fine. Drop the Geist of Saint Traft on turn 3, and make your opponent hate you more by dropping this fellow turn 4 and NOT soulbonding to the Geist. When Geist attacks, this triggers the 4/4 Flying Angel to enter the battlefield tapped and attacking, which triggers another "dost thou desire to soul bond?" trigger. This time, you gleefully accept, producing your turn four 4/4 Flying, Double Strike Angel of doom swinging in.

The best part is that once the angel token is exiled at the end of combat, Mr. Silverblade Paladin here is now unpaired, and free to be paired with the next 4/4 Flying Angel produced on the next attack, and then on the Second Main Phase of turn 5 with your new jerk of a 5/3 Flying, Indestructible, Double Strike Angelic Overseer (Yay for this guy being a Human!).

...Unless you were just saying you wanted Taft to survive due to Double Strike, in which case sometime... (see all)

Leads to a lot of free wins with Boros Aggro in block (and maybe even standard) with stuff like:

posts.post_content: Uhhhhh willieskyeyes, firstly, knights steer their mounts with their knees, their horses are highly trained and respond to shifting pressure on their sides. Secondly that is a halbard, not a scythe, and it is currently behind held like that because he looks to be initiating a charge. Most knights had a side arm like a sword because lances are a little difficult to use after the initial charge (you don't have enough space to swing or thrust and people have a nasty ha bit of getting stuck on them and breaking them off. If we are going to be talking about the size of weapons on horseback, have you ever SEEN a couched lance? The only thing wrong with this picture is that he should be holding a more traditional lance and maybe have a helmet on / more armouring for the horse
posts.html:
Uhhhhh willieskyeyes, firstly, knights steer their mounts with their knees, their horses are highly trained and respond to shifting pressure on their sides. Secondly that is a halbard, not a scythe, and it is currently behind held like that because he looks to be initiating a charge. Most knights had a side arm like a sword because lances are a little difficult to use after the initial charge (you don't have enough space to swing or thrust and people have a nasty ha bit of getting stuck on them and breaking them off. If we are going to be talking about the size of weapons on horseback, have you ever SEEN a couched lance?
